note_text:
INDICATION FOR OPERATION:  This is a 74 year old-year-old male chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and a right upper lobe (RUL) nodule.  The nature, purpose, risks, benefits and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.  Patient indicated a wish to proceed with surgery and informed consent was signed.
CONSENT : Obtained before the procedure. Its indications and potential complications and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate. The patient or surrogate read and signed the provided consent form / provided consent over the phone. The consent was witnessed by an assisting medical professional.
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: R91.1 Solitary Lung Nodule J44.9 COPD
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:  R91.1 Solitary Lung Nodule J44.9 COPD

ANESTHESIA: 
General Anesthesia

MONITORING : Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENT : 
Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope
Ion Robotic Bronchoscope

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS:   Minimum

COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).

Initial Airway Inspection Findings:
    The therapeutic flexible bronchoscope was introduced through the endotracheal tube adaptor and advanced into the trachea. The trachea was thoroughly examined, revealing a sharp carina. The bronchial tree was inspected bilaterally to the subsegmental level, with the mucosa appearing smooth and uniformly pink. No nodularity, lesions, abnormal secretions, airway narrowing, or distortion was noted.

Navigation and Targeting:
A CT chest scan was displayed on a separate planning station to generate a three-dimensional rendering of the pathway to the target. The navigational plan was reviewed, verified, and loaded into the robotic bronchoscopy platform.
Robotic navigation was performed using the Ion platform with partial registration. The Ion robotic catheter was advanced to the Anterior Segment of RUL (RB3), targeting a lesion approximately 1.4 cm in diameter. Under navigational guidance, the catheter was advanced to within 2.5 cm of the planned target.
Cone Beam CT Imaging:
A cone beam CT was obtained using the Cios Spin system with a low-dose spin protocol. Three-dimensional reconstructions were performed on an independent workstation, and the images were transmitted to the Ion platform. Based on the updated nodule location, the Ion robotic system was adjusted accordingly. I personally reviewed and interpreted the cone beam CT and 3D reconstructions.
Transbronchial Needle Aspiration (TBNA):
A TBNA was performed using a 23G needle via the extended working channel catheter. A subsequent low-dose CT spin confirmed appropriate tool placement within the lesion. Additional TBNA samples (total of six) were then obtained using both 21G Needle and 23G Needle. All samples were sent for Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal) and Cytology.
Transbronchial Cryobiopsy:
Transbronchial cryobiopsies were performed using a 1.1 mm cryoprobe via the extended working channel catheter with a freeze time of 6 seconds per sample. A total of five samples were collected and sent for Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal) and Cytology.
Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL):
A BAL was performed through the extended working channel catheter by instilling 20 cc of normal saline, with 10 cc returned. Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal) and Cytology. 
Rapid On-Site Evaluation (ROSE):
ROSE from the Ion procedure revealed Atypical cells present but no evidence of malignant neoplasm, suggesting an inflammatory or infectious process
Additional BAL:
After completion of the robotic bronchoscopy, the therapeutic bronchoscope was reinserted, and a BAL was performed in the Apical Segment of RUL (RB1). Forty cc of normal saline was instilled with a 20 cc return, and samples were sent for Cell Count.
Chartis Evaluation:
A Chartis evaluation of the left upper lobe was performed to assess for collateral ventilation in anticipation of future endobronchial valve (EBV) treatment. Balloon occlusion using the Chartis system in the target left upper lobe confirmed the absence of collateral ventilation as evidenced by the cessation of the air leak.

The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate complications.  At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition. 

SPECIMEN(S): 
TBNA (RUL): Peripheral nodule sample sent for pathology and culture.
Transbronchial Cryobiopsies (RUL): Peripheral nodule samples sent for pathology and culture.
BAL (RUL): Specimen sent for respiratory and fungal cultures, AFB, and cytology.

IMPRESSION/PLAN: This is a 74 year old-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for evaluation of an RUL peripheral nodule as well as a Chartis examination of the left upper lobe in preparation for potential EBV treatment. Collateral ventilation status was confirmed.

Transfer to PACU
Obtain chest X-ray
Discharge home once cleared by PACU
Await path and culture results and based on findings f/u for EBV insertion for COPD

lines.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with transbronchial lung biopsy(s), single lobe
lines.selection_reason: Transbronchial cryobiopsy performed on RUL nodule. Modifier 59 applied to unbundle from TBNA (same site, different modality, typically bundled but distinct diagnostic work here - or consider XS if payer requires). Note: TBLB and TBNA at same site are bundled per NCCI. Modifier 59 allows unbundling if distinct session/lesion/medical necessity. Here it is same lesion. **Strict NCCI interpretation suggests bundling 31628 into 31629 or vice-versa depending on valuation, usually report both with modifier if distinct diagnostic intent (e.g. lymph node vs mass). Here both are RUL nodule. Often bundled. However, KB rules suggest reporting with modifier for distinct lesions/locations. Assuming clinical necessity for both needle and cryo samples.** Correct coding: Often bundled. If distinct, -59. Let's include with -59 for completeness of procedure capture, subject to payer rules.

lines.selection_reason: BAL performed in RUL (RB3 and RB1). Distinct from biopsy. NCCI may bundle with biopsy codes. Modifier 59 indicated for separate diagnostic service (microbiology).

lines.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with balloon occlusion, assessment of air leak, airway sizing, and documentation
lines.selection_reason: Chartis evaluation performed in LUL. Distinct anatomic site (LUL) from biopsy (RUL). Modifier 59/XS justified.

rules_applied.details: Base scope inspection is part of the surgical package.

rules_applied.description: Fluoroscopy (76000) and Post-op CXR (71045) are bundled.
rules_applied.details: Imaging guidance and routine post-op checks are not separately reportable.

rules_applied.description: Moderate sedation (99152/99153) dropped because General Anesthesia was provided by Anesthesiologist.
rules_applied.details: Proceduralist cannot bill sedation when anesthesia professional is present.

global_comments: Patient underwent robotic bronchoscopy (Ion) with TBNA and Cryobiopsy of RUL nodule, plus Chartis of LUL.
Correctly coded as 31629 (TBNA) + 31628-59 (Cryo TBLB) + 31624-59 (BAL) + 31634-59 (Chartis LUL) + 31627 (Nav).
Modifier -59 (or -XS) essential for 31634 (distinct LUL site) and 31628/31624 (distinct services/site overlap management).
Moderate sedation not billed (General Anesthesia).

changes: Updated billing RVUs to match 2025 Facility Fee Schedule (Total: 24.36, Work: 15.70).

note_text:
INDICATION FOR OPERATION: This  is a 68 old-year-old male who presents with multiple sub centimeter solid and cavitary pulmonary nodules.  The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.  Patient indicated a wish to proceed with surgery and informed consent was signed.
 
CONSENT: Obtained before the procedure. Its indications and potential complications and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate. The patient or surrogate read and signed the provided consent form / provided consent over the phone. The consent was witnessed by an assisting medical professional.
 
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:  Multiple Lung Nodule

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:  Multiple Lung Nodule
  
ANESTHESIA: 
General Anesthesia with local anesthesia (Lidocaine 1% solution, total 60 mg)
 
MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
 
INSTRUMENTS: 
Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope
Radial EBUS
Ion
 
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS:   Minimum Blood Loss
 
COMPLICATIONS:    Post-procedure PTX (no intervention required)
 
PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
 
Initial Airway Inspection Findings:
Normal appearing airway and mucosa to the segmental level bilaterally
 
Robotic navigation bronchoscopy was performed with Ion platform.  Full registration was used.  

Target 1:   Ion robotic catheter was used to engage the Lateral Basal Segment of RLL.  Target lesion is about .6 cm in diameter.   Under navigational guidance the ion robotic catheter was advanced to 1.0 cm away from the planned target. Endoscopically abnormal tissue could be visualized within the airway.
 
Radial EBUS was performed to confirm that the location of the nodule is unable to be visualized.  The following features were noted: aerated lung.
 
Transbronchial needle aspiration was performed with 21G Needle and cytology brush through the extended working channel catheter under fluoroscopic guidance. ROSE indicated inflammatory tissue with atypical cells. Samples sent for Cytology. Transbronchial biopsies were then performed with standard forceps in similar fashion. Samples were sent for histology and culture. 
 
Target 2: Ion robotic catheter was then used to engage the Posterior Segment of RUL.  Target lesion is about .5 cm in diameter and cavitary.   Under navigational guidance the ion robotic catheter was advanced to 1.0 cm away from the planned target. 

Radial EBUS was performed to confirm that the location of the nodule is unable to be visualized.  The following features were noted: aerated lung.

Transbronchial needle aspiration was performed with 21G Needle and cytology brush through the extended working channel catheter under fluoroscopic guidance. ROSE was non-diagnostic. Samples sent for Cytology.
 
Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed in the RLL.  Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 30 cc of NS.  Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal) and Cytology.
 
Prior to withdrawal of the bronchoscope, inspection demonstrated no evidence of bleeding.
 
Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Left Mainstem, Carina, RUL Carina (RC1), RML Carina (RC2) and Left Carina (LC2) from mucus and blood clots. 
 
The patient tolerated the procedure well.  At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition. Post-operative CXR demonstrated moderate PTX which was stable on repeat in asymptomatic patient. Patient was discharged with close follow-up and instructions for parameters to seek emergency care.   
 
SPECIMEN(S): 
RLL: TBNA, Brush, Biopsy, BAL
RUL: TBNA
 
IMPRESSION/PLAN: Eduardo Santiago is a 68 old-year-old male who presents with multiple sub centimeter solid and cavitary pulmonary nodules 
-Follow up biopsy results
-Follow-up PTX with visit next week 
-RTC and emergency return parameters given.

General anesthesia used; moderate sedation codes are not applicable.
Brushing (31623) bundled with biopsy/TBNA of same lesions.
Radial EBUS (+31654) included despite note saying 'unable to visualize' because the attempt was made for localization during intervention.
Post-procedure pneumothorax coded with J95.811.

changes: Corrected billing RVUs to 2025 standards (Total: 27.31, Work: 17.73). Previous values were inconsistent.

note_text:
INDICATIONS:  1.Bronchus-intermedius obstruction 
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. Following intravenous medications as per the record a laryngeal mask airway was inserted. Topical anesthesia was then applied to the upper airway and the T190 video bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. The laryngeal mask airway was in good position. The vocal cords appeared normal. The subglottic space was normal. The tracheal carina was sharp. All left sided airways were normal. The right mainstem and right upper lobe were normal. In the proximal bronchus intermedius there was a completely obstructing polypoid endobronchial mass. We were able to bypass the mass with the flexible bronchoscope and the distal airways were filled with purulent secretions consistent with post-obstructive pneumonia, the secretions were suctioned through the bronchoscope. At this point the flexible bronchoscope and LMA were removed and a 12 mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope was inserted through the mouth into the distal trachea and advanced into the right mainstem bronchi before attaching the monsoon JET ventilation. Using the flexible bronchoscope gentle manipulation resulting in brisk bleeding which was controlled with topical epinephrine and TXA. The mass was soft and somewhat pulsatile. We then inserted the linear EBUS bronchoscope into the airway and assessed the lesion with ultrasound. There was no obvious tumor seen and multiple vessels visualized in proximity to the lesion. At this point we decided to abort the procedure as endobronchial debulking would likely result in massive hemorrhage. The rigid bronchoscope was then removed from the airway and the procedure completed. Post-procedure a CT Angiogram of the chest was performed which showed purtruding submucosal broncholith with right middle and lower lobe atelectasis. There was also a very small apical pneumothorax which likely was caused by post-procedure coughing as no intervention was actually performed. 
Complications: Small pneumothorax, likely related to post-procedure coughing. 
Recommendations:
- Admit to IM ward
- Repeat CXR is 6 hours to assess pneumothorax
- Treat for post-obstructive pneumothorax with course of oral antibiotics
- I will reach out to thoracic surgeons at high volume centers to discuss possible surgical removal of broncholith.

clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Post-procedure CT Angiogram showed protruding submucosal broncholith with right middle and lower lobe atelectasis. Small apical pneumothorax.

equipment.bronchoscope_model: T190, 12 mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope, Linear EBUS

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Vocal cords, subglottic space, trachea, carina, and left airways normal. Right mainstem and RUL normal. Completely obstructing polypoid endobronchial mass in proximal bronchus intermedius.

complications.other_complication_details: Brisk bleeding controlled with epinephrine and TXA; Small apical pneumothorax likely related to coughing.

outcomes.procedure_aborted_reason: Risk of massive hemorrhage due to vascularity of lesion/broncholith
outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: Admit to IM ward, antibiotics for post-obstructive pneumonia, Thoracic Surgery consultation

linear_ebus_stations_detail.notes: Used for vascular assessment; no tumor seen; multiple vessels in proximity; no aspiration performed.

cao_interventions_detail.notes: Completely obstructing polypoid mass (submucosal broncholith); gentle manipulation caused brisk bleeding; procedure aborted.

lines.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with therapeutic aspiration of tracheobronchial tree, initial
lines.selection_reason: Therapeutic aspiration of purulent secretions from distal airways performed to treat post-obstructive pneumonia. Rigid bronchoscopy (31622) is bundled.

note_spans.snippet: distal airways were filled with purulent secretions... secretions were suctioned

lines.description: Bronchoscopy, diagnostic
lines.selection_reason: Bundled into 31645.

lines.description: Bronchoscopy with tumor excision
lines.selection_reason: Procedure aborted before excision could be performed; 'gentle manipulation' causing bleeding does not constitute excision. 31645 covers the completed therapeutic work.

per_code.summary: Selected for therapeutic aspiration of purulent secretions. Although the intended debulking (31640) was aborted, the aspiration of the post-obstructive pneumonia was successfully completed, making 31645 the most accurate reflection of the therapeutic work performed.

documentation_evidence.snippet: distal airways were filled with purulent secretions... secretions were suctioned

per_code.summary: Diagnostic bronchoscopy is bundled when therapeutic bronchoscopy (31645) is performed.

global_comments: Debulking (31640) was aborted due to bleeding risk/vascularity; no excision was performed.
Rigid bronchoscopy was used but does not have a separate add-on code; it is the method of delivery.
Linear EBUS was used for inspection/vascular assessment only (no TBNA), so no 31652/31653 is reported.
Hemostasis (Epi/TXA) is considered incidental to the manipulation and aborted attempt.

metadata.notes: Procedure aborted due to vascularity/broncholith; aspiration completed.

changes: Verified billing values (31645); no changes needed.

note_text:
Indications: adenopathy and multiple pulmonary nodules 
Medications: Propofol infusion via anesthesia assistance  
Procedure, risks, benefits, and alternatives were explained to the patient. All questions were answered and informed consent was documented as per institutional protocol. A history and physical were performed and updated in the preprocedure assessment record. Laboratory studies and radiographs were reviewed. A time-out was performed prior to the intervention. 
Following intravenous medications as per the anesthesia record and topical anesthesia to the upper airway and tracheobronchial tree the Q190 video bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth. The vocal cords appeared normal. The subglottic space was normal. The trachea is of normal caliber. The carina was sharp. All left and right sided airways were normal without endobronchial disease. The video bronchoscope was then removed and the UC180F convex probe EBUS bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. Sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed in the station 4R, 11R, 7 lymph nodes All samples were sent for routine cytology. We then removed the EBUS bronchoscopy and the ultrathin bronchoscope was inserted and based on anatomical knowledge advanced into the right middle lobe to the area of known nodule and lesion distal endobronchial lesion was identified with both white light and radial EBUS. Biopsies were then performed with a variety of instruments to include peripheral needle forceps and brush. After adequate samples were obtained the bronchoscope was removed. 
Complications: No immediate complications
Estimated Blood Loss: Less than 5 cc.
Post Procedure Diagnosis:
- Flexible bronchoscopy with successful biopsy of right lobe middle lobe nodule
- Successful EBUS bronchoscopy with biopsy  
- Await final pathology

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Normal vocal cords, subglottic space, trachea, and carina. Normal left and right sided airways without central endobronchial disease (prior to EBUS/Ultrathin).

navigation_targets.notes: Lesion identified with both white light and radial EBUS; biopsied with peripheral needle forceps and brush.

outcomes.preliminary_diagnosis: Successful biopsy of right middle lobe nodule and EBUS staging

Propofol via anesthesia assistance documented; proceduralist moderate sedation codes (99152/99153) omitted.

RML lesion described as 'distal endobronchial', supporting 31625 over 31628 (transbronchial).
Sedation provided by anesthesia, so no moderate sedation billing.

note_text:
Indications: Chronic cough, history of BMT 
Medications: Fentanyl 125mcg, Versed 4mg  

Procedure, risks, benefits, and alternatives were explained to the patient. All questions were answered and informed consent was documented as per institutional protocol. A history and physical were performed and updated in the pre-procedure assessment record. Laboratory studies and radiographs were reviewed. A time-out was performed prior to the intervention. 
Following intravenous medications as per the record and topical anesthesia to the upper airway, the Q190 video bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, into the oropharynx. The oropharynx and larynx were well visualized and normal. There was normal vocal cord motion and no vocal cord lesions. Additional topical anesthesia with 1% lidocaine was applied to the larynx and subsequently throughout the tracheobronchial tree for a total of 18 cc. The bronchoscope was then advanced through the larynx into the trachea. The tracheal mucosa was boggy and edematous. There were thick purulent secretions noted throughout the airways. The bronchoscope was then advanced into the right mainstem. Each segment and sub-segment within the right upper, right middle, right lower lobe was well visualized. The right sided airway anatomy was normal and mucosa was boggy and erythematous as seen in the trachea with thick purulent secretions throughout the airway. Bronchial lavage of the lower lobe secretions was obtained (20cc in 10cc out). There were no specific masses or other lesions were identified throughout the tracheobronchial tree on the right. The bronchoscope was then withdrawn into the trachea and then advanced into the left main stem and each segment and sub-segment in the left upper lobe, lingula and lower lobe was visualized. The left sided airway anatomy was normal and mucosa was boggy and erythematous as seen in the other airways with thick purulent secretions throughout the airway. The bronchoscope was then wedged in the right middle lobe and bronchoalveolar lavage was performed with instillation of 90 cc of saline and return of 40 cc of lavage fluid. The bronchoscope was then withdrawn from the wedged position and after removing from trap remaining secretions were suctioned clear. The bronchoscope was then withdrawn. The patient tolerated the procedure well without evidence of desaturation or complications.
Findings:
Diffusely edematous and erythematous airways with copious thick secretions.
No endobronchial lesions visualized

Recommendations:
Will await culture, cytology and cell count from lavage
Will initiate mucous clearance regiment with 3% saline neb TID, Flutter valve

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Oropharynx/larynx normal. Tracheal mucosa boggy/edematous with thick purulent secretions. Right and Left systems: Normal anatomy, boggy/erythematous mucosa, thick purulent secretions throughout.

outcomes.preliminary_diagnosis: Diffuse airway edema and erythema with purulent secretions
outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: Await culture/cytology. Initiate mucous clearance with 3% saline neb TID, Flutter valve.

cpt_codes.description: Moderate sedation services provided by the same physician; initial 15 minutes

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with bronchoalveolar lavage
lines.selection_reason: BAL performed in RML (90cc in/40cc out) is the primary diagnostic procedure.

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; diagnostic, with cell washing
lines.selection_reason: Bundled into 31624 (BAL) when performed in the same session per NCCI.

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with therapeutic aspiration of tracheobronchial tree
lines.selection_reason: Therapeutic aspiration is considered bundled or incidental to BAL/Wash unless significant separate work for 'retained secretions' causing obstruction is documented. 'Secretions suctioned clear' is typically integral to the exam.

lines.description: Moderate sedation services provided by the same physician; initial 15 minutes
lines.selection_reason: Moderate sedation (Fentanyl/Versed) managed by proceduralist. Time not explicitly stated but implied.

qa_flags.message: Sedation time not explicitly documented. 99152 requires >10 minutes of intraservice time.

per_code.summary: Selected as primary. Documentation confirms lavage of the RML with 90cc saline. This is the highest-valued procedure performed.

documentation_evidence.snippet: bronchoalveolar lavage was performed with instillation of 90 cc of saline

per_code.summary: Dropped. Diagnostic bronchoscopy and bronchial washing (RLL) are bundled into the BAL code (31624) per NCCI and CPT guidelines.
Candidate code for moderate sedation. Fentanyl/Versed administered by proceduralist team. Requires time documentation to be fully compliant.

global_comments: Primary procedure is BAL (31624).
Bronchial washing (31622) is bundled.
Therapeutic aspiration (31645) not supported as distinct/primary service; suctioning appears incidental to clearing secretions for visualization/lavage.
Verify sedation time for 99152.
